docs.lead_paragraph: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
docs.abstract: In this lesson, students research diseases associated with celebrities and then create an original television public service announcement that explains the disease and its human impact.
docs.snippet: In this lesson, students research diseases associated with celebrities and then create an original television public service announcement that explains the disease and its human impact.

byline.original: By AMANDA CHRISTY BROWN and BRIDGET ANDERSON

docs.lead_paragraph: From diabetes to flu to AIDS, almost every disease kills men sooner than women, causing some to ask:  Is men’s health getting short shrift?

headline.main: Health Disparities Persist for Men, and Doctors Ask Why
headline.print_headline: Health Disparities Persist for Men, and Doctors Ask Why

docs.snippet: From diabetes to flu to AIDS, almost every disease kills men sooner than women, causing some to ask:  Is men’s health getting short shrift?

docs.lead_paragraph: With the rise of new tests, some doctors face an uncertain future.

headline.main: New Tests, New Future for Doctors
headline.print_headline: New Tests, New Future For Doctors

docs.snippet: With the rise of new tests, some doctors face an uncertain future.

docs.lead_paragraph: Countless celebrity patients are now associated with various diseases. What lessons do these cases teach the public?

headline.main: Famous Patients and the Lessons They Teach
headline.print_headline: Famous Patients and the Lessons They Teach

docs.lead_paragraph: Robert N. Butler is dedicated to the health of the aged and  says that the elderly still get the short shrift.

headline.main: Focusing on the Issue of Aging, and Growing Into the Job
headline.kicker: A Conversation With Robert N. Butler
headline.print_headline: Focusing on the Issue of Aging, and Growing Into the Job

docs.snippet: Robert N. Butler is dedicated to the health of the aged and  says that the elderly still get the short shrift.

docs.lead_paragraph: In recent years, women's health has been a national priority. Pink ribbons warn of breast cancer. Pins shaped like red dresses raise awareness about heart disease. Offices of women's health have sprung up at every level of government to offer information and free screenings, and one of the largest government studies on hormones and diet in aging focused entirely on older women. Yet statistics show that men are more likely than women to suffer an early death.

headline.main: Health Disparities Persist for Men, and Doctors Ask Why

docs.abstract: Health experts question why men continue to be at greater risk of early death from health conditions than women; Dr Demetrius J Porche, Louisiana State University's Health Sciences Center School of Nursing associate dean, discusses his work as editor of new quarterly American Journal of Men's Health and his dedication to providing better medical information for men; research shows that men are at medical disadvantage from moment of conception; behavior is thought to play role, but many suggest there are other elements involved in disparity; drawing; graph (L)
docs.snippet: In recent years, women's health has been a national priority. Pink ribbons warn of breast cancer. Pins shaped like red dresses raise awareness about heart disease. Offices of women's health have sprung up at every level of government to offer...

docs.lead_paragraph: Sometimes those things that are meant to help cure you can hurt you instead.
docs.snippet: Sometimes those things that are meant to help cure you can hurt you instead.

docs.lead_paragraph: A New Jersey couple filed suit against Aetna Inc., claiming that it refused to fully cover their daughter’s treatment for anorexia.

headline.main: Insurer Sued for Refusing to Pay Costs of Anorexia
headline.print_headline: Insurer Sued For Refusing To Pay Costs Of Anorexia
